hints_html:
The derivative of \(f\) at \(x\) is the slope of the line tangent to \(f\) at \(x\). What is the expression for the slope of a line?

The slope of a line between two points \(\displaystyle (x_1, f(x_1))\) and \(\displaystyle (x_2, f(x_2))\) is \(\frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1}\). What happens as \(\displaystyle x_2 - x_1 \to 0\)? How can we express this mathematically?

The limit definition of the derivative of \(f\) at \(x\) is \(f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\).

Equivalently, the derivative of \(f\) at \(a\) is \(f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}\).

hints_raw:

The slope of a line between two points <math>\displaystyle (x_1, f(x_1))</math> and <math>\displaystyle (x_2, f(x_2))</math> is <math>\frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1}</math>. What happens as <math>\displaystyle x_2 - x_1 \to 0 </math>? How can we express this mathematically?

sols_html:
By the limit definition of the derivative of \(f\) at \(x\),

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\frac{x+h}{2(x+h)+1} - \frac{x}{2x+1}}{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{(x+h)(2x+1) -x(2(x+h)+1)}{h(2(x+h)+1)(2x+1)} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{(2x^2 + x + 2xh + h) - (2x^2 + 2xh + x)}{h(2(x+h)+1)(2x+1)} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{h}{h(2(x+h)+1)(2x+1)} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{1}{(2(x+h)+1)(2x+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{(2(x+0)+1)(2x+1)} \\ &= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{(2x+1)^2}}\end{aligned}\]

Use of the quotient rule confirms that this is indeed \(\displaystyle f'(x)\):

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{1 \cdot (2x+1) - x \cdot 2}{(2x+1)^2} \\ &= {\color{OliveGreen} \frac{1}{(2x+1)^2}}\end{aligned}\]

By the alternative limit definition of the derivative of \(f\) at \(a\),

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a} \\ &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{\frac{x}{2x+1} - \frac{a}{2a+1}}{x-a} \\ &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{\frac{x(2a+1) - a(2x+1)}{(2x+1)(2a+1)}}{x-a} \\ &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{\frac{(2ax+x) - (2ax+a)}{(2x+1)(2a+1)}}{x-a} \\ &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{\frac{x - a}{(2x+1)(2a+1)}}{x-a} \\ &= \lim_{x \to a}\frac{1}{(2x+1)(2a+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{(2a+1)^2} \\ f'(x) &= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{(2x+1)^2}}\end{aligned}\]

Use of the quotient rule confirms that this is indeed \(\displaystyle f'(x)\):

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{1 \cdot (2x+1) - x \cdot 2}{(2x+1)^2} \\ &= {\color{OliveGreen} \frac{1}{(2x+1)^2}}\end{aligned}\]
